channel.title: SOPA/Protect IP Act awareness
channel.description:
I believe most of you are redditors (so you should know about this bill unless if you don't check /all/ and you're unsubscribed to /politics/ and /technology/), along with some of you being American.
My question is this: Why hasn't there been any type of SOPA/Protect IP Act awareness on any of these forums (mscp, gamedev, etc). These forums will be blocked, most likely shut down if either of these bills are passed (both bills have a lot of co-sponsors plus a lot of lobbyists). Post an announcement on all forums stating why this bill can't be passed, and how to protest it.
Anyways, if you haven't heard of these bills, check http://americancensorship.org/.
To help protest, sign petitions (there are some in the link above), transfer all your domains away from GoDaddy(largest domain register I believe, and they support SOPA), and spread the word about this shit bill. Considering most of the bill's supporters are media outlets(CBS, Fox, etc), there hasn't been much media attention to this.
Also, yes, I know, this is old fucking news.

item.title: SOPA/Protect IP Act awareness
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

[quote author=Mopman link=topic=529183.msg3863537#msg3863537 date=1324810167]

[quote author=Lothy link=topic=529183.msg3863363#msg3863363 date=1324789901]
Game studios know that DRM is going to be cracked at some stage. Its purpose is to ensure that the game remains uncracked for long enough to make some sort of profit. If a game goes 6 months without being cracked then that’s 6 months of sales before people will even have the chance to consider an alternative means of acquiring the game.
[/quote

does anything last anywhere near 6 months though? the only thing i can think of is syncrosofts mcfact stuff, but that isnt really suitable for games
[/quote
Fail quote.

Read full topic

@sanga282 wrote:

Lothy:

Game studios know that DRM is going to be cracked at some stage. Its purpose is to ensure that the game remains uncracked for long enough to make some sort of profit. If a game goes 6 months without being cracked then that’s 6 months of sales before people will even have the chance to consider an alternative means of acquiring the game.

if that were the case then they’d remove the DRM with an update once it had been cracked so it didnt continue to piss people off. Also most games get cracked in what like a day?

Read full topic

Game studios know that DRM is going to be cracked at some stage. Its purpose is to ensure that the game remains uncracked for long enough to make some sort of profit. item.title: SOPA/Protect IP Act awareness
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:24, topic:426488”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=529183.msg3861874#msg3861874 date=1324706238]

its the companies’ fault if their product can be pirated. Guard against it. Digital retailers get the luxury of selling infinite copies of their product, the least they can do is develop anti-pirating mechanics.

thats called DRM and that hurts the legitimate customers more than pirates
[/quote]That’s a bullshit argument and you know it. Very few DRM’s affect the legit end user in a signficiant way. The exceptions are shit gay systems like the one Ubisoft employs, but those are hardly the norm.[/quote]
i didnt say it as the norm, but it does happen a lot. Spore had a shitty one that they faced lawsuitsfor i think. I did some digging and found Mass effect had a crappy 10 day reactivation, rainbow 6 vegas had an update that crippled the game with DRM, bioshock had secuROM issues etc etc and then you’ve got ubisofts shit stick which plagues eveyr game they produce now. DRM is a massive issue, it needn’t exist as it doesn’t actually do anything. I’ve yet to come across a DRM system that can’t be cracked and beaten (although saying that I like serious sam 3 BFE’s method of DRM in which an invincible pink scorpion chases you around with two assault rifles for the entirety of the game and I think it’s always in there with pirated games, not sure.)

Read full topic

item.title: SOPA/Protect IP Act awareness
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:27, topic:426488”][quote author=Cole1497 link=topic=529183.msg3861441#msg3861441 date=1324692769]
if this passes it gives american law enforcement the right to punish you for piracy crimes even if you don’t live in america
[/quote]

How the fuck are they going to do that? Send Seal team 6?[/quote]
They’re DEVGRU now, not Seal Team 6.

Read full topic

item.title: SOPA/Protect IP Act awareness
item.dc:creator: @fellixombc fellixombc
item.description:
@fellixombc wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:11, topic:426488”]I am on EFF’s mailing list so I’ve known about this for some time:

Electronic Frontier Foundation – 11 Dec 11

Fight the Blacklist: A Toolkit for Anti-SOPA Activism

Congress is debating dangerous legislation that would give the Department of Justice unprecedented power to “blacklist” websites without a trial and give Hollywood copyright holders a new way to shut down a website’s financial services for alleged...

I’ve emailed all of my representatives regarding this, one of them actually responded. I don’t know what else I can do in regards to this for now.[/quote]
Inform the morons over at mscp, considering they don’t have a clue whats going on and they claim it won’t affect them in anyway.

Niall:

[quote author=fellixombc link=topic=529183.msg3860826#msg3860826 date=1324666814]My question is this: Why hasn’t there been any type of SOPA/Protect IP Act awareness on any of these forums (mscp, gamedev, etc).

the reason it hasn’t been posted here is probably because sopa bullshit is plastered over every website and its dog with the tagline “I can’t believe it hasn’t been posted here yet”

I’m sure general awareness is high enough that anyone who understands what sopa will do already knows about it[/quote]
Oddly enough, I visited many forums and they claimed they haven’t heard a single thing about it. Anyways, SOPA isn’t the real threat at the moment, but PIPA is. PIPA will be voted on in the senate (http://www.techdirt.com/articles/20111217/22470217117/senator-harry-reid-moves-to-approve-protect-ip-begin-censoring-internet.shtml). It passed the house. It passed the senate judiciary committee. It’s a good chance that it will get passed. Hopefully the bill gets revoked for violating freedom of speech if it does pass the senate (or if Obama did something useful and veto the bill). Either way, I’m investing my money into an offshore vpn.

Read full topic
